>>Erika: Hi everyone and thanks for coming
to, today's Authors at Google event and I'm

4.text:
very pleased to welcome Josh Sundquist. Josh
is the author of the national best seller,

9.text:
"Just Don't Fall" and he's been featured on
CNN, USA Today and NPR. He's appeared on national

16.text:
television to present an award to Lance Armstrong
and was featured on the back of Doritos bags

21.text:
nationwide, as the founder of Less Than 4.org,
the world's largest online community for amputees.

27.text:
He has spoken to hundreds of thousands of
people across the country, including audiences

32.text:
at Fortune 500 companies, inner-city public
schools, and the White House. And his hobbies

38.text:
include par-3 golfing, tying bow ties, and
combing his hair. So please join me in welcoming

45.text:
>>Josh Sundquist: Thank you Erika. Sweet.
So thanks for coming out this morning. I just

53.text:
got locked in the hallway using your restroom
and it was a very scary moment for me because

58.text:
I was locked in. I was like, wow, these people
are waiting for me to give a speech and I'm

62.text:
locked in this hallway. And there's a sign
there that says like, "Do Not Allow Anyone

66.text:
To Go Through This Door". Like don't let anyone
piggyback on you. So I'm like now I'm going

69.text:
to have to convince someone to break the rule
on this sign. And then this guy came out and

74.text:
I was like, yo. So I showed him my badge and
I was like, 'Look, I'm supposed to speak in

77.text:
here. Can you let me in?' He's like, 'Alright.
What are you speaking about?' And that's always

81.text:
a weird question for me to answer, and so,
and I'm just not good at answering it in an

85.text:
exciting way. I was like, "Myself." And he
was like, 'Oh, ok.' But he let me in, so we're

91.text:
good. So let me ask you guys a question, what
was, what was the first thing, and this is

101.text:
like interactive, this is not a, um, what
do you call it? What's a question that like

104.text:
doesn't have an answer, you know what I'm
talking about?

107.text:
>>Josh Sundquist: Rhetorical, yes. This is
not a rhetorical question. Neither was that

110.text:
as it turns out. So here is my non-rhetorical
question for you. And you can just yell out

116.text:
answers if you don't want to go on the microphone.
What was, what's your name with that just

121.text:
>>Josh Sundquist: Jason. Jason, what was the
first thing that you remember wanting when

125.text:
you were a kid? Like the first like toy or
like shiny thing that you wanted?

like a little toolbox.

or they were like the plastic kind?

162.text:
>>Josh Sundquist: Nice. And can we VC in people

168.text:
So, I don't, this is a very confusing looking
screen to me. But if people that are VCing,

what is something? Is there, is that like

It's pretty amazing. So, uh, would someone

191.text:
at one of our VC locations. What's something
that you guys remember wanting when you were

201.text: >>Josh Sundquist: Legos. And who said that?

>>Josh Sundquist: Mike. Nice to meet you,
Mike. Where are you?

>>male audience member #3: Dude, ah San Bruno

208.text:
>>Josh Sundquist: Oh, sweet. Well, nice to
meet you and thanks for watching. Legos, huh?

211.text:
Dude, Legos were, I felt like always so expensive.
You know? Like I always really wanted them,

219.text:
>>male audience member #3: The really big
sets, the best ones, yeah.

222.text:
>>Josh Sundquist: Yeah, yeah. There'd be like
these incredibly, there'd be like a castle

225.text:
that's like life-sized, it'd be like a thousand
dollars. Um, but those were always sweet.

230.text:
Sweet. So we got Legos, tool box, transformers.
So I remember for me like the first thing

235.text:
I remember really wanting when I was a kid
was a, what happened I had this sort of transformation

241.text:
moment. Like I was nine years old and I walked
into my Sunday School class actually at church

246.text:
and I saw this kid that I knew named Aaron.
And Aaron was wearing this, this lime green

252.text:
travel soccer team uniform. It had like polyester
jersey and shorts and knee-high socks and

258.text:
leather cleats. And I at this time I had two
legs and I was sort of a casual soccer hobbyist

263.text:
I guess you would say. And and I saw though
this uniform for this travel soccer team and

268.text:
I was just like, ahhh, that is amazing. I
have to get one of those. And it was like

274.text:
from that moment on it was, that was just
like my purpose in life was to get a travel

279.text:
soccer team uniform. But, you remember how
it was when you were a kid, right, when you

285.text:
were looking forward to a certain thing, whether
that was you know getting your tool box thing

292.text:
or it was like Christmas or your birthday
or the travel soccer team tryouts, right,

295.text:
and you were just like so excited about this
certain day, but time moves so slowly, right?

301.text:
And it just seemed like that day was never
gonna come, you know? But the funny thing

307.text:
for me is that in this particular instance
it actually never did, because literally the

314.text:
exact same week that I was supposed to try
out for this, this travel soccer team, I woke

321.text:
up from a biopsy because I'd been having this
like pain in my leg. And I'll never forget

326.text:
it, I'm waking up and I'm sure some of you
guys have been under anesthesia at some point,

330.text:
and I'm waking up and sort of groggy and blinking
off this anesthesia, and my mom and my dad

335.text:
walked into the room and they stood on the
left side of my bed and my dad looked down

341.text:
at me and he said, "Joshua, the doctors, the
doctors found cancer in your leg." And they

349.text:
told me that I had a 50 percent chance to
live. Like I said, I was nine years old. I

357.text:
started chemotherapy. I lost my hair, which
at that time was a really big deal for me,

364.text:
like I was very like meticulous at a young
age about combing my hair. I would sort of

369.text:
like use like half a bottle of gel and like
slick it back like a 1950's movie star or

375.text:
something. And I always used, I don't know
if you guys are much into hair care products,

378.text:
but I used not just any gel. I used L.A. Looks
gel. Yeah, like level 5, most extreme hold,

385.text:
the red kind with all of the bubbles in it.
I would get it at the Dollar Store. It was

388.text:
awesome. So then for me to like lose my hair
was this sort of really, like really devastating

394.text:
thing for me as a nine year old and furthermore
to sort of lose everything that I had come

398.text:
to know as my life because I had no energy.
I spent one week out of every three in the

404.text:
hospital. I felt sick and tired all the time.
And after three months of this treatment,

410.text:
my parents told me that the chemotherapy wasn't
working and that in order to save my life,

418.text:
my leg was gonna have to be amputated. I remember
they told me this. We were sitting in our

423.text:
driveway and I was in the back seat of the
minivan and my mom and my dad were up front.

428.text:
I remember feeling like all of the oxygen
had just been like sucked out of the van,

434.text:
you know, because it was all I could think
about was that, you know that lime green travel

441.text:
soccer team uniform, because I knew that I
was never going to wear it. It's like, this

451.text:
is the way I would describe it to you. You
know I think like I'm sure yours is the same

456.text:
way, but I have in my mind what I imagine
sort of as a metaphor of this like sort of

460.text:
photo album of things I imagine are going
to happen in the future that are going to

465.text:
be awesome. Like for example right now in
my photo album I imagine that on the train

470.text:
on the way back today, I'm going to watch
awesome like stuff on my IPad. I'm gonna reply

475.text:
to a bunch of Tweets. It's gonna be great.
And then this weekend, my brother's coming

479.text:
into, town, which is gonna be awesome. And
then, what's gonna happen after that? Oh,

484.text:
I just hit 99,000 subscribers yesterday on
YouTube, which is like really exciting for

488.text:
me. So very soon I'm gonna hit 100,000 subscribers
probably in like three or four days. So that's

493.text:
gonna be amazing. And then my YouTube channel's
gonna grow even more and then at some point

497.text:
I'm becoming very rich and famous as a result
of YouTube and my book. And then all of the

502.text:
girls that have ever liked me are gonna write
me a collective e-mail. It'll be like "Josh,

505.text:
we are so sorry. We were totally wrong about
you. We're so sorry we rejected you." But

509.text:
by then it won't really matter because I'll
be married to this really hot girl. And by

513.text:
hot of course I mean she'll have a great personality
and we're gonna have a house and it's gonna

517.text:
be designed by an interior decorator. And
it's gonna have awesome furniture from IKEA,

521.text:
because that's my favorite furniture store,
'cause I'm not a snob. And it's just gonna

525.text:
be so awesome. Right? That is what I imagine
in my current photo album of hope. I don't

530.text:
know what's in yours, maybe something similar.
But for me at age nine, that, that photo album,

537.text:
every. every picture was me wearing this,
this soccer uniform. I remember after my parents

544.text:
told me that I was gonna lose my leg, it was
like I went back to that that photo album,

550.text:
you know to, the way you do sort of on a daily
basis to sort of recover from some emotional

555.text:
problem, right? And I went back to that that
photo album and it was just like every, every

561.text:
page was just blank. It was like everything
that I hoped for was seemingly gone. I lost

572.text:
my leg then probably about four weeks after
that conversation. And after I did I was very

579.text:
sort of eager to [drinking] get back to um,
to playing sports in some way. And so I remember

586.text:
I went to about probably a month after I lost
my leg I went to play in my church's, we had

593.text:
this like softball game, this like big annual
softball game. And so I decided I was going

597.text:
to go play in this, this game. And I remember
when I was supposed to up to bat, I sat my

602.text:
crutches down on the ground and I hopped over
to, to home base and I sat there and you have

610.text:
to know at this point you know I didn't have
hair of course, so I was wearing a, you know,

615.text:
a ball cap to cover my my bald head and I
was very like thin and and pretty sick and

619.text:
pretty pale. At that point I weighed just
over 60 pounds. And I had no balance because

625.text:
I'd just lost my leg and after you lose your
leg you have to sort of re, ah, readjust and

630.text:
relearn your center of balance. So I had to
lean on the bat as if it were a cane until

636.text:
Pastor Smuland, who was the pitcher, pitched
this ball towards me. And then I waited and

642.text:
I waited and at the last minute right before
it came in front of me, I picked the bat up

646.text:
and I swung and I missed and the bat went
flying and I fell down on the ground in this

656.text:
sort of dry, dusty infield. It made me start
coughing. But I sat there and then I stood

662.text:
up and I brushed myself off and I picked up
the bat because it was like this game was

667.text:
a really big deal to me because I wanted to
prove to, to myself but also like all my friends

674.text:
from church and my dad who was there like
watching from behind the chain link fence,

678.text:
I wanted to prove to everyone that I, I could
still do stuff even though I had one leg.

684.text:
Like I could still play things and play in
sports just like I did before. So this was

689.text:
a big moment for me. And the second pitch
came and again I swung and I missed. And then

699.text:
the pitcher, the catcher threw the ball over
to Pastor Smuland. And I remember this moment

703.text:
because, let me ask you all, I'm not sure
if any of you all have children, but what's

709.text:
what is like the universal advice that you
give children who are up to bat? [pause]

714.text:
>>male audience member #4: Keep your eye on
the ball.

718.text:
>>Josh Sundquist: Keep your eye on the ball.
Exactly. What's your name?

720.text:
>>Josh Sundquist: Todd. Yeah. Keep your eye
on the ball. Right? Always. Everybody, choke

723.text:
up on the bat. Keep your eye on the ball.
Boom. You're golden. Right? So, I'm sitting

727.text:
there and and I remember I, I looked over
at my dad, who was, as I said, standing behind

732.text:
the chain link fence, and he said, "Joshua,
keep your eye on the ball." So I was like,

740.text:
alright. So on this third pitch, as it came
towards me, I tried to keep my eye on the

746.text:
ball. And as it came across home base, I swung
and I missed. And I, I fell down in the dirt

757.text:
and then I picked up my crutches and I started
to, to walk off the field. And as I did, I

765.text:
heard Pastor Smuland, he yelled at me, he's
like, "Where're you going?" And I was like,

771.text:
"Well I, I struck out." And Pastor Smuland
yelled back at me. He's like, "We're Protestants,

779.text:
brother. We play by grace not by the law."
And I was like, what? What is a Protestant?

787.text:
I do not understand what you are saying to
me. But it was like all of the adults were

790.text:
sort of chuckling and so I figured that this
meant I was allowed to keep swinging. So I

796.text:
went back up and I got another pitch and another
strike and another and another and another.

802.text:
And after nine strikes, I started to see my
vision get blurry. And, like I said, all my

810.text:
friends from church were there and I couldn't
let them see me cry. So again I picked up

815.text:
my crutches and I started to walk off the
field like as fast as I could. But this time

821.text:
I heard my dad yell at me. He said, "Joshua,
you almost had that last one." And I stopped

830.text:
and I looked over my shoulder at him. And
my dad, he put his, his two fingers in between

838.text:
the openings in this chain link fence and
he said, "It was this close." I remember standing

848.text:
there and looking at him and it was like my
my dad was my hero and I knew that if he were

859.text:
up to bat that he would keep swinging until
he got a hit. So I went back up and I picked

869.text:
up the bat again and another pitch came and
another strike and another and another. But

874.text:
finally on the 13th pitch, I felt the ball
bounce off the bat and I watched it roll up

882.text:
the infield and by the time it reached the
shortstop, my friend Tim, who was my designated

890.text:
runner, was already on first base. [pause]
And I tell you that story today for two reasons.

900.text:
Number one, because I think that there's nothing
really better that that you and I could aspire

908.text:
to in life than to be like my dad was for
me that day, to be a hero to someone else.

919.text:
But secondly because, if you think about it,
that softball game is a lot like life, because

927.text:
in life, unlike normal softball, you get as
many strikes as you want. You know you only

935.text:
strike out when you quit. And I don't know
about you, but I'm surprised by how often

941.text:
as an adult I'm willing to quit after just
one strike in a new endeavor. [pause] As I

950.text:
said that softball game was a big moment for
me because it sort of showed me that I could

956.text:
still, I could still play sports on some level.
And a few months went by and I was still on

963.text:
chemotherapy, but I heard that there was a
group of kids from the hospital where I was

968.text:
treated at, University of Virginia Children's
Hospital, that was going up to the local ski

971.text:
resort where I'm from in Virginia, which is
called Massanutten. And so I was, I was like

976.text:
really excited about this so I went up and
I learned how to ski and it was awesome and

979.text:
the third time I went to ski was this sort
of recreational level race for children with

984.text:
disabilities towards the end of the season
in March. And by this time I was, I was just

990.text:
about to finish up the chemotherapy, so I
was still on treatment, and it was I guess

994.text:
probably 10 months after I'd lost my leg.
And I was still, I think, very much psychologically

1001.text:
still stuck in the idea that I had lost the
chance to be able to wear that uniform, that

1007.text:
I was never gonna be a soccer player. And
I remember I went through the course on this

1012.text:
ski race and it was very exciting and very
fun and I got to the end and I skidded to

1015.text:
a stop after I went through the finish line
and I was standing there. I was very tired

1019.text:
and I was breathing hard and I was wearing
a toboggan cap over my bald head and this

1023.text:
man that I had never seen before, he walked
over to me and he set his hand on my shoulder

1030.text:
and he said, "Son, I used to coach something
called the United States Paralympic Ski Team,

1037.text:
and I think that you have great potential."
And I looked at this guy and I saw his boots

1044.text:
and I looked from his boots and I saw his
pants. And his pants were red and they were

1048.text:
white and they were blue. And then I looked
up from there and I saw that the jacket matched

1053.text:
the pants. And I was like, 'Sign me up for
these Paralympics that you speak of, sounds

1060.text:
excellent.' But I guess, you know, it's like
when when you're a kid you have this, this

1068.text:
moment like that where you, you have this
thing that you want to do but you don't really

1072.text:
know how to do it and so I had that in my
mind but it took many years before I became

1078.text:
a ski racer. And yet that moment itself was
so transformational because, 'cause that coach

1085.text:
took me from a place as I said of looking
back at the sport I could no longer play and

1092.text:
showed me an opportunity for a uniform that
I never knew existed. [pause] What sport I

1101.text:
wonder is it that that you can no longer play?
Or that I can no longer play? One thing I've

1109.text:
learned is that sometimes, sometimes the path
changes and you have to, you have to choose

1119.text:
a new uniform. As I said, I didn't really
start ski racing in a serious way until I

1125.text:
was about 16 years old, [pause] which was
a momentous year for me in many respects.

1131.text:
In my family, I grew up in this sort of very
conservative family. We weren't allowed to

1135.text:
date until we were 16 years old and so when
I was 16 was not only the year I started ski

1141.text:
racing, but it was also the first time I ever
went on a date. And I took this girl from

1146.text:
my high school named Amy Gardner out to play
golf and the reason because where I'm from

1151.text:
in Harrisonburg, Virginia, there's this free
par 3 golf course, right, which is awesome.

1154.text:
So we went out. We were having this great
time, and I hit this brilliant shot off the

1159.text:
sixth tee on the course. It like soared through
the air and it came down and bounced a couple

1164.text:
times. It stopped like maybe three feet away
from the hole. And I was just so excited,

1169.text:
right? Because I'm like, I'm like man you
know this shot's so awesome. She's gonna be

1173.text:
so impressed. She's totally gonna make out
with me. It's gonna be amazing. And so I'm

1177.text:
getting all excited. I'm like Yes! Yes! Right?
And I'm sort of like jumping around and I'm

1182.text:
wearing my artificial leg at the time. Now
it was Todd, right? Todd, something that you

1187.text:
should know about artificial legs that you
might not depending on your expertise level

1191.text:
with prosthetics, is that they come preprogrammed
to malfunction at the worst possible moments

1199.text:
in your entire life. So I will give you a
slow-motion demonstration of what happened.

1204.text:
I was like Yes! Yes! Ohhhhhhh. Right I fall
down on the ground and it is very awkward

1216.text:
because like no one ever knows what do you
do when the guy with one leg falls down? Like,

1224.text:
are you allowed to laugh at him? Should you
help him up? Maybe like take him to therapy

1229.text:
of some sort? Like nobody knows. And I stand
up. True story. I don't know how this happened,

1233.text:
but I looked down and the foot on my artificial
leg is literally turned around backwards.

1239.text:
So you can imagine the other golfers on the
golf course are looking at me like, yeah,

1245.text:
911? I have a very serious golfing emergency
to report to you. This guy's foot is like

1250.text:
broken off. And I'm trying to figure out like
how to sort of remedy this problem and so

1257.text:
I walk over to the edge of the golf course
and I, I take my artificial foot and I just

1263.text:
start kicking it against a tree to try to
pop the foot back into place. Which is awesome

1270.text:
because I feel like at that point the other
golfers are looking at me like, 'Yeah this

1273.text:
guy has some serious anger management problems
that he needs to work out in his life.' But

1280.text:
I'll never I'll never forget though this one,
this one moment right after I'd stood up and

1286.text:
I you know I saw my foot was sort of turned
around backwards and I remember thinking like

1290.text:
oh, this is my first date with Amy Gardner
and she is so hot and now it is ruined. But

1297.text:
then I thought. 'You know this is my first
date with Amy Gardner and you only get one

1304.text:
first date, so why would I let it be ruined?'
So what did I do? I got up. I laughed about

1320.text:
it. I tried to get the foot sort of popped
back into place and then I played that next

1326.text:
hole of golf. And see what I realized that
day is that we can't always choose what happens

1335.text:
to us, but we can always choose what we want
to do about it. [pause] As I said, that was

1345.text:
also the year I started ski racing. And I
uh, I was very excited about racing [pause]

1350.text:
because I was like man, this is this is how
I'm gonna get a uniform and I wanted to go

1354.text:
to the Paralympics. And 2006 was my goal in
Torino, Italy. And I also, I had this idea

1360.text:
that I was gonna be this just sort of prodigy
of ski racing and I was gonna roll up to my

1364.text:
first ski race and that it was like an able-bodied
race, I was the only person there with one

1368.text:
leg, but I was sure I was gonna like win and
everyone's gonna be like, 'Man, this guy is

1372.text:
so good. Where did he come from? It's just
like magical.' Like I really, I was 100 percent

1377.text:
convinced of this. But what actually happened
was that in my first race, I fell five times

1381.text:
and I was last place by far. It was like the
winning time was 30 seconds and my time was

1386.text:
like 2 minutes and 30 seconds. So I had no
really natural talent whatsoever. But I was

1392.text:
very determined to -- I guess, you know, it
was funny as we got closer to 2006 I started

1398.text:
racing full time and I lived Colorado during
the winters to train. But I still was never

1403.text:
very good and it was becoming sort of obvious
that I was probably not going to make the

1408.text:
Paralympics. In fact, like the head coach
of my program in Winter Park sat me down and

1414.text:
told me he didn't think my chances were good.
And I was like, well what would you say would

1417.text:
be my actual like statistical probability
of making the Paralympics? And he was like,

1422.text:
'I'd say about one in a million.' And I was
like, 'Oh, well thank you for your honesty,

1427.text:
I guess.' That was my coach. Really encouraging.
Awesome. But I was like you know to me I guess

1434.text:
I got to a point where it wasn't really about
necessarily making the Paralympics or not

1438.text:
making the Paralympics. It was about not having
regrets. It was about 20 years in the future

1443.text:
not looking back and saying, 'Man, like if
I had just trained that, that last season,

1447.text:
you know it could have happened.' And so I
went into that last season, the 2006 season,

1454.text:
I suppose with that that attitude and to make
a long story short, I got lucky a few times,

1461.text:
I had a few good races and in March of 2006,
well. Hmmm. In March of 2006, well before,

1473.text:
before I get to that, let me tell you about
something else. Because I think that that,

1480.text:
that day in March of 2006 was the most beautiful
walk of my entire life. But to understand

1487.text:
that in context I think I have to tell you
about the toughest walk of my life which was

1493.text:
in July of 1994. I remember that morning I
checked into the hospital with my mom and

1500.text:
my dad and we sat down in chairs in this waiting
room and I set my crutches down on the ground.

1508.text:
By this point I'd been on crutches for maybe
three months because the cancer in my left

1513.text:
leg. you know, it was in my femur and I wasn't
supposed to walk on my leg. It was very fragile.

1518.text:
I set my crutches down on the ground as I
said and I, I bent over and I wrapped my arms

1523.text:
around my left leg and I remember it was just,
I was like so so quiet in this room. And we

1533.text:
sat like that for a long time. And eventually
a doctor and a nurse came in. I remember the

1541.text:
nurse was pushing an empty wheelchair and
the doctor looked down at me and he said,

1548.text:
"We're ready, we're ready to take you back
now." And I remember I looked at that wheelchair

1558.text:
[pause] and I looked at him and I said, "I
think that I'm going to walk." And I'll never

1570.text:
forget walking down that hallway. If you've
ever been in the hospital you know you wear

1577.text:
those those brown terrycloth socks that have
the rubber strips on the bottom. I remember

1583.text:
I could feel that cool hospital linoleum floor
underneath those brown terrycloth socks. And

1591.text:
I knew that those would be the last, the last
steps that I would ever take with, with two

1600.text:
legs. [pause] I think that, I think that we
can all agree probably that that we have days

1612.text:
from time to time, you know, when it feels
like everything, everything in our lives is

1620.text:
falling apart. And I don't know about you,
but for me I just hope that in those sorts

1626.text:
of moments I will always find the, the courage
to be able to walk. [pause] I was in the hospital

1641.text:
for awhile after the amputation and I spent
nine months on chemotherapy after that, so

1647.text:
in total I was on treatment for a year and
I spent about 100 days in the hospital. But

1651.text:
at the end of that year is when I met that
coach who told me about the Paralympics and

1655.text:
three years later I was declared cured of
the cancer and three years after that was

1659.text:
when I was 16 and when I started racing. And
six years after that was March of 2006, when

1667.text:
I walked into the opening ceremonies of the
Paralympics in Torino, Italy. There was 30,000

1677.text:
people in this stadium, including my dad,
who had first told me that I had cancer 12

1686.text:
years before, and my mom, who had first told
me that my leg was going to be amputated.

1691.text:
And as I walked into that stadium, I was wearing
a uniform. Not the lime green soccer uniform

1702.text:
I thought that I would wear as a kid, but
one that it turns out was even better. It

1707.text:
was red and white and blue and it said U.S.A.
See one thing that I've learned is that sometimes

1718.text:
the uniform that we get is better than the
one that we thought we wanted. And the other

1726.text:
thing I've learned is that, well I didn't
start ski racing until after I lost my leg

1734.text:
because you know I couldn't play soccer anymore,
right? It was, it was like something I could

1738.text:
do as an amputee. Which means, that if you
think about it, the most beautiful walk of

1743.text:
my life only happened because of the toughest
walk of my life 12 years before on that hospital

1755.text:
tile linoleum floor. Which is why I think
that that life, no matter how tough it is,

1764.text:
and make no mistake that life is tough, that
the fact that we woke up today for another

1772.text:
day means that life is beautiful. [pause]
Those I think are all of the sort of the most

1785.text:
important things that have happened to me
and that I've learned from them that I can
